Sarah Fortan is a courageous young woman.  one who already is wise beyond her years. She lived a lifetime in a matter of weeks last month, not knowing whether she would live or die as she faced drawn guns at the Kabul airport. Sarah, we are grateful that you and your family are safely back home. And we have great hope that your family members who are yet to join will safely do so very soon. text: Good evening board members, I just wanted to give you a quick hiring update since I did a little bit of that last month. Next month at the October business meeting the team from human resources will be here to go into a much more depth in depth hiring report but to date we have hired 191 teachers.  90 of those teachers are at the elementary level, 101 are at the secondary level. As I shared the last time, this has been a pretty challenging year when it comes to hiring for all of our positions, both teaching staff and support staff. We still have three full-time positions still to go.  We are still looking to hire a full-time middle school exploratory teacher, a Spanish teacher, and a special education teacher. All of those searches are in process and we are hoping that those will be filled in the very near future. We also have several part-time positions across the school division of foreign language in the elementary school teacher.  to very part-time ESOL positions, a part-time talent development, and a part-time intervention. Again, all of these searches are in process. And like all of our positions, if we do not have a teacher in that role at this time, we have hired substitutes to cover, and we are working as quickly as possible to get those positions filled with the right people. As far as our support services go, in our school-based support services, we have still a range of classified positions.  several teaching assistants, a nurse, an OA, a couple of long term subs, and other positions. And then in our building support, building services, we're still looking to hire five people, one in the Department of Technology,  four in EDEP, three in fiscal services, 11 for child nutrition, and we're still looking for 18 in transportation. Obviously, the lack of these positions being filled forces our directors and our principals to think creatively to make sure that the work is getting done and accomplished in various and creative means, but hopefully we'll be at normal capacity and full capacity very shortly.  So again, I just wanted to provide you a brief highlight, and the HR team will be here next month. Thank you.

Another critical area that's kind of, it's not tied to this but it bears mentioning is also our school nurses. They are also another employee group that's really taken on the brunt of the pandemic. text: Dr. Haas, Mr. Page, members of the school board, school leadership, teachers, and parents. Our names are Michael and Rochelle Kang. Thank you for the opportunity to talk with you today regarding our concerns about the mask mandates on disabled children and the impact of their education.  We are both physicians as well as parents of a student at Stone Robinson Elementary. I work at Martha Jefferson Hospital and Mike works at UVA. We have been in the center of the COVID crisis as professionals and as parents. We understand the stress on the medical community, parents, and educators. Our daughter Malia is a third grader at Stone Robinson Elementary and is in the special education class.  She has Angelman syndrome, so she is nonverbal and has seizures, physical disabilities, and sensory issues. We have tried multiple programs with occupational therapists and behavioral therapists at both home and school to help her wear a mask. But as recognized by her neurologist and her developmental pediatrician, she is not able to wear a mask despite our efforts. Her physicians have written a letter of mask exemption from public spaces. Special education staff recognize her inability to keep the mask on.  On the day before school started, we received a phone call that our daughter would not be able to attend school because she was not able to keep a mask on. We were offered virtual school as the only option, which we know caused regression for our daughter last year. As physicians, we support mask mandates, but we were taken aback by the response of the special education department and their handling of the news. Parents who reached out to the special education leadership were sent an email with minimal explanation.  Parents are left confused it felt discriminatory and insensitive to the needs of our children. Thankfully we have an incredible group of teachers and staff at Stone Robinson have stepped into the gap. They have designed individual programs for special education students allow them to have outdoor learning opportunities. We appreciate all of the efforts to integrate educate our child but this model is also not sustainable as it is weather weather dependent.
speaker: rachellekeng

text: We are speaking out today because we like to collaborate with Dr. Haas, the school board, and the community physician advisors to be a part of the team that designs a safe learning environment for all, while not punishing disabled students who cannot wear a mask. We like to be a part of the medical advisory team to represent the children with special needs so that their voices and their families are heard.  Is there a middle ground for our students that still allows us to follow CDC VDH guidelines and to ensure the safety of all staff and children? COVID is evolving and dynamic and we need long-term solution. As the weather cools, our children will no longer be able to attend outdoor school. The gap of access to education will only increase. We would like to discuss options for ventilated large indoor spaces to bring our children into school areas designed for those who cannot wear masks.  We would also like to follow the mitigation measures to make sense for the prevalence of COVID infections specific to our community. Some of these extreme measures may be hurting our children more than helping them. We recognize that our children are a minority of the student body. We also recognize the safety of all those involved is paramount, but let us work together as a team to think of creative solutions that do not discriminate nor punish our children.  Please remember the children who are severely affected by your mask policies. Please reassure us that you are working on ways to bring our children back into the schools. We appreciate your attention today and appreciate everything that you've done through this pandemic. Thank you very much for your time this evening.
speaker: rachellekeng

The request addresses key themes of equity, safety, investment in existing facilities, as well as new investments needed to support the long-term capacity needs of our growing county. The COVID-19 pandemic has not slowed the construction of new development in Albemarle County, and ACPS must continue planning efforts to accommodate the student population growth. As Albemarle County is expected to grow by 44% over 30 years, adequate capacity will continue to be a need for the school division.  This is supported by the 10-year enrollment projections and reinforced by both the recently completed development and student yield analysis and the 30-year population forecast. One of our talented committee members has created a data visualization tool to help us see the capacity conflicts over time.  In the Tableau application, users can click through and see year-to-year changes as well as summary views. We've included some screenshots in this presentation as a preview. The screenshot shows the elementary capacity conflicts during our last normal fall enrollment year.  You can see that Mountain View, Brownsville, Baker Butler, and Crozet have the highest conflicts filled at over 100% capacity. As we move through the years, the Crozet expansion will relieve capacity conflicts at Crozet and Brownsville. The enrollment at both Baker Butler and Mountain  By the time we reach 10 years out, there are other schools that are close to 100% capacity, including Murray, Stony Point, and Stone Robinson. At the middle school levels, we are currently in the blue with regards to capacity conflicts.  In five years, though, we anticipate three of our five comprehensive middle schools to be at 95% capacity, with our smallest school at only 70% of capacity. Interestingly, in 10 years, trends continue to shift. With the complication of split feeder patterns and under-enrollment at some schools, further study to determine feasible alternatives is needed.  At the high school levels, capacity issues are both a historical, current, and future concern. While the program at Center One has added 150 additional seats at the high school level, and we continue to offer options for alternative learning, a long-term solution is needed. At the high school levels, for over 15 years, the school division has been in a practice of expanding existing facilities, and when necessary, deploying mobile classroom units in the interim.  As these schools reach a point where expansion is no longer practical, the committee recommends a strategy for land acquisition and construction of new facilities. The high school project would fund comprehensive updates on instructional and support spaces at Albemarle and Western Albemarle high schools, based on the recommendations of a master plan study that is scheduled to be completed next year. Just as a brief personal story, this project is dear to my heart because my oldest daughter, Elena Handy, attends Monticello High School as an 11th grader, and she has cerebral palsy. However, recently she suffered a minor injury and has been forced to use her wheelchair for the past week.  And the only elevator is in the center of the building, and it has greatly increased her travel time. She's therefore been choosing between leaving class early or arriving to class late. And I recognize that one student story shouldn't be the sole factor in making funding decisions. However, this is a good example of how bringing our infrastructure up to modern standards will have a tangible impact on equity.  The data center is another project that's been requested in previous years, and this project would fund the construction of a secure primary data center for the entire county school system. It will support the servers and network equipment essential to all areas of the school division, including both operations and instruction.  And just to provide a little visual here of the current data center and a view of what we aspire to, the current data center houses the majority of our server equipment, but lacks many of the safety measures that we really need to protect our data. For example, it does not have fire suppression equipment or hardened construction. And in fact, it has been subject to flooding in recent years.  Finally, one new project in the request is for improved air quality. COVID-19 has highlighted the importance of our school HVAC systems and the need to deliver outside air at levels greater than our current design. This project will take a holistic approach to improving building HVAC systems beyond our baseline design criteria.  And since the committee finalized its recommendations, we have learned of a potential federal funding source that could offset the cost of the project by up to $2.7 million. If the project qualifies for this funding, ACPS would be required to provide a one-to-one match. Staff are working on reviewing the requirements of this opportunity.  Before we end our portion of the presentation, we did want to highlight one of our recommendations that isn't directly linked to a project, nor requires specific investments, tangible like we've described. We would like the school board to adopt a policy on school sizes at each level, including a capacity range to help guide the committee in considering the efficacy of the expanding and or constructing school buildings and making future recommendations.  We've worked with staff already to pull Education Advisory Board research and other data to aid in the development of this policy, but please provide staff with additional data requests. And I'll hand it back off to Maya.
speaker: jason
